Refinements of the Bell and Stirling numbers

Tanay Wakhare∗ ∗ University of Maryland, College Park, MD 20742, USA twakhare@gmail.com
Abstract.

We introduce new refinements of the Bell, factorial, and unsigned Stirling numbers of the first and second kind that unite the derangement, involution, associated factorial, associated Bell, incomplete Stirling, restricted factorial, restricted Bell, and r𝑟r-derangement numbers (and probably more!). By combining methods from analytic combinatorics, umbral calculus, and probability theory, we derive several recurrence relations and closed form expressions for these numbers. By specializing our results to the classical case, we recover explicit formulae for the Bell and Stirling numbers as sums over compositions.

1. Introduction

The Bell and Stirling numbers have been studied for over a century because of their importance to many combinatorial problems. They frequently arise in enumeration problems in combinatorics, and also satisfy many complex identities and inter-relations [4, 11]. In this paper, we present refinements of the Bell and Stirling numbers that preserve many essential structural properties of their classical counterparts. In particular, they satisfy many of the same inter-relations and recurrence relations because the associated generating functions have a simple form which enables us to follow classical proofs of many identities. They also unite several previously disparate generalizations of the Stirling and Bell numbers.

We use a variety of methods to then explore their properties; we begin with an analytic combinatoric construction of their generating function, followed by umbral and generating function methods to derive identities for these numbers. Finally, an explicit probabilistic representation allows us to construct some new and extremely interesting expressions for the Bell and Stirling numbers as sums over compositions.

Let S𝑆S be a nonempty (and possibly infinite) set of indices. We consider generalized Bell numbers Bn,Ssubscript𝐵𝑛𝑆B_{n,S}, defined as the number of ways to partition n𝑛n into blocks, where each block has a size which is found in S𝑆S. We also consider the generalized factorial numbers An,Ssubscript𝐴𝑛𝑆A_{n,S}, which count the number of permutations of n𝑛n labeled elements into cycles, such that each cycle has a number of elements that belongs to the index set S𝑆S. For example, with S={1,3}𝑆13S=\{1,3\}, A4,S=9subscript𝐴4𝑆9A_{4,S}=9 and B4,S=5subscript𝐵4𝑆5B_{4,S}=5. The relevant partitions for B4,Ssubscript𝐵4𝑆B_{4,S} are

We introduce

[nk]S,subscriptmatrix𝑛𝑘𝑆\begin{bmatrix}n\\ k\end{bmatrix}_{S},

the generalized (unsigned) Stirling numbers of the first kind, which count the number of permutations of n𝑛n elements with k𝑘k cycles, such that each cycle has a cardinality found in S𝑆S. We also introduce

{nk}S,subscriptmatrix𝑛𝑘𝑆\begin{Bmatrix}n\\ k\end{Bmatrix}_{S},

the generalized Stirling numbers of the second kind, which count the number of partitions of n𝑛n into k𝑘k boxes, such that each box has a cardinality found in S𝑆S. These have two free variables, and contain more combinatorial informations than the Bell and factorial numbers.

We also need to define initial values, since setting the following values allows us to concisely state consistent generating function identities. These definitions are consistent with initial values for the classical case [4]. For n≥1𝑛1n\geq 1, we set

[n0]S=[0k]S=[n0]S={0k}S=0.subscriptmatrix𝑛0𝑆subscriptmatrix0𝑘𝑆subscriptmatrix𝑛0𝑆subscriptmatrix0𝑘𝑆0\begin{bmatrix}n\\ 0\end{bmatrix}_{S}=\begin{bmatrix}0\\ k\end{bmatrix}_{S}=\begin{bmatrix}n\\ 0\end{bmatrix}_{S}=\begin{Bmatrix}0\\ k\end{Bmatrix}_{S}=0.

We also set

[00]S=[00]S=1,subscriptmatrix00𝑆subscriptmatrix00𝑆1\begin{bmatrix}0\\ 0\end{bmatrix}_{S}=\begin{bmatrix}0\\ 0\end{bmatrix}_{S}=1,

and note that from the combinatorial definition

[nk]S=[nk]S=0subscriptmatrix𝑛𝑘𝑆subscriptmatrix𝑛𝑘𝑆0\begin{bmatrix}n\\ k\end{bmatrix}_{S}=\begin{bmatrix}n\\ k\end{bmatrix}_{S}=0

for k>n𝑘𝑛k>n.

Directly from the combinatorial definitions, we see that we have the equations

Bn,S=∑k=0n{nk}Ssubscript𝐵𝑛𝑆superscriptsubscript𝑘0𝑛subscriptmatrix𝑛𝑘𝑆B_{n,S}=\sum_{k=0}^{n}\begin{Bmatrix}n\\ k\end{Bmatrix}_{S}

and

An,S=∑k=0n[nk]S.subscript𝐴𝑛𝑆superscriptsubscript𝑘0𝑛subscriptmatrix𝑛𝑘𝑆A_{n,S}=\sum_{k=0}^{n}\begin{bmatrix}n\\ k\end{bmatrix}_{S}.

Therefore, we set the initial values

A0,S=B0,S=1.subscript𝐴0𝑆subscript𝐵0𝑆1A_{0,S}=B_{0,S}=1.

These numbers have been studied for many special values of the index set S𝑆S. The case S=ℤ≥1={1,2,…}𝑆subscriptℤabsent112…S=\mathbb{Z}_{\geq 1}=\{1,2,\ldots\} yields the classical Bell, Stirling, and factorial numbers since these do not have any restrictions on cycle length or box size. The cases S={1,2,…,k}𝑆12…𝑘S=\{1,2,\ldots,k\} and S={k,k+1,…}𝑆𝑘𝑘1…S=\{k,k+1,\ldots\} are referred to as Bn,≤ksubscript𝐵𝑛absent𝑘B_{n,\leq k}, Bn,≥ksubscript𝐵𝑛absent𝑘B_{n,\geq k}, An,≤ksubscript𝐴𝑛absent𝑘A_{n,\leq k}, and An,≥ksubscript𝐴𝑛absent𝑘A_{n,\geq k}, and have been extensively studied several times [12, 13]. In another direction, S={1,2}𝑆12S=\{1,2\} means that Bn,S=An,Ssubscript𝐵𝑛𝑆subscript𝐴𝑛𝑆B_{n,S}=A_{n,S} yield the involution numbers [1] and S={2,3,4,…}𝑆234…S=\{2,3,4,\ldots\} leads to the derangement numbers [3]. Extending our study of Stirling numbers from these particular index sets S𝑆S to the general case allows us to prove general theorems that apply to every special case. It also leads to identities that are very non-intuitive combinatorially, guiding future work.

2. Symbolic Methods

Here we present the basic ideas of analytic combinatorics, which trivializes the proof of our generating functions. For further details of the theory described in this section, refer to Flajolet and Sedgewick [7]. The main idea of this symbolic method is to write our combinatorial constructions as the composition of several basic operations on a single element. We can then algorithmically read off a generating function for our combinatorial quantity from this sequence of operations.

We consider exponential generating functions (EGFs), which naturally correspond to labeled objects. Ordinary generating functions correspond to unlabeled objects. Some of the most basic constructions for labeled elements (there are subtle differences for unlabeled objects) are S​U​M𝑆𝑈𝑀SUM, P​R​O​D𝑃𝑅𝑂𝐷PROD, S​E​Q𝑆𝐸𝑄SEQ, S​E​T𝑆𝐸𝑇SET, and C​Y​C𝐶𝑌𝐶CYC. Given that A​(z)=∑nan​znn!𝐴𝑧subscript𝑛subscript𝑎𝑛superscript𝑧𝑛𝑛A(z)=\sum_{n}a_{n}\frac{z^{n}}{n!} and B​(z)=∑nbn​znn!𝐵𝑧subscript𝑛subscript𝑏𝑛superscript𝑧𝑛𝑛B(z)=\sum_{n}b_{n}\frac{z^{n}}{n!} are the EGFs of {an}subscript𝑎𝑛\{a_{n}\} and {bn}subscript𝑏𝑛\{b_{n}\}, the operation S​U​M𝑆𝑈𝑀SUM produces an EGF for {an+bn}subscript𝑎𝑛subscript𝑏𝑛\{a_{n}+b_{n}\} - the number of elements of size n𝑛n, following pointwise addition of A𝐴A and B𝐵B. This is trivially A​(z)+B​(z)=∑n(an+bn)​znn!,𝐴𝑧𝐵𝑧subscript𝑛subscript𝑎𝑛subscript𝑏𝑛superscript𝑧𝑛𝑛A(z)+B(z)=\sum_{n}(a_{n}+b_{n})\frac{z^{n}}{n!}, but other operations allow us to construct very nontrivial generating functions.

The remaining operations are:

  • •

    P​R​O​D​(ℬ,𝒞)𝑃𝑅𝑂𝐷ℬ𝒞PROD(\mathcal{B},\mathcal{C}), which gives an EGF for the cardinalities of the “labeled product" of {an}subscript𝑎𝑛\{a_{n}\} and {bn}subscript𝑏𝑛\{b_{n}\}, which consists of the set of ordered pairs {(an,bn)}subscript𝑎𝑛subscript𝑏𝑛\{(a_{n},b_{n})\} after an order consistent relabeling. This is given by A​(z)×B​(z)𝐴𝑧𝐵𝑧A(z)\times B(z)

  • •

    S​E​Q​(ℬ)𝑆𝐸𝑄ℬSEQ(\mathcal{B}), which corresponds to an EGF for the number of sequences of a given size with parts in ℬℬ\mathcal{B}, is given by 11−B​(z)11𝐵𝑧\frac{1}{1-B(z)}. S​E​Qk​(ℬ)𝑆𝐸subscript𝑄𝑘ℬSEQ_{k}(\mathcal{B}), corresponding to the size of all k𝑘k-element sequences, is given by B​(z)k𝐵superscript𝑧𝑘{B(z)^{k}}.

  • •

    S​E​T​(ℬ)𝑆𝐸𝑇ℬSET(\mathcal{B}) corresponds to forming all sequences, taken modulo an equivalence relation identifying all sequences that are permutations of each other. This is given by exp⁡(B​(z))𝐵𝑧\exp\left(B(z)\right). S​E​Tk​(ℬ)𝑆𝐸subscript𝑇𝑘ℬSET_{k}(\mathcal{B}), the set of all k𝑘k-sequences modulo this same equivalence relation, is given by B​(z)kk!.𝐵superscript𝑧𝑘𝑘\frac{B(z)^{k}}{k!}.

  • •

    C​Y​C​(ℬ)𝐶𝑌𝐶ℬCYC(\mathcal{B}) corresponds to S​E​Q​(ℬ)𝑆𝐸𝑄ℬSEQ(\mathcal{B}), taken modulo an equivalence relation identifying sequences whose elements are cyclic permutations of each other, and is given by log⁡11−B​(z)11𝐵𝑧\log\frac{1}{1-B(z)}. C​Y​Ck​(ℬ)𝐶𝑌subscript𝐶𝑘ℬCYC_{k}(\mathcal{B}), the set of k𝑘k-sequences modulo this same equivalence relation, is given by B​(z)kk𝐵superscript𝑧𝑘𝑘\frac{B(z)^{k}}{k}.

Using just these few operations (there are more!) allows us to write

Theorem 1.

We have the following constructions:

where 𝒵𝒵\mathcal{Z} is an “atomic class" of a single element of size one.

Proof.

We give an example for how to translate this into a generating function; the given EGFs follow from interpreting 𝒵𝒵\mathcal{Z} as the variable z𝑧z, and then formulaically applying the rules for symbolic constructions.

We begin with the combinatorial definition of [nk]Ssubscriptmatrix𝑛𝑘𝑆\begin{bmatrix}n\\ k\end{bmatrix}_{S}, the number of permutations of n𝑛n labeled elements with k𝑘k cycles, such that each cycle has a cardinality found in S𝑆S. We first form the sum ∑s∈SC​Y​Cs​(𝒵)subscript𝑠𝑆𝐶𝑌subscript𝐶𝑠𝒵\sum_{s\in S}CYC_{s}(\mathcal{Z}). Since each C​Y​Cs𝐶𝑌subscript𝐶𝑠CYC_{s} operator is invariant under a cyclic permutation of its sequences, it enumerates the number of cycles of length s𝑠s. The sum over s∈S𝑠𝑆s\in S then corresponds to the fact that we allow a cycle to have any cardinality found in our index S𝑆S. S​E​Tk𝑆𝐸subscript𝑇𝑘SET_{k} then composes k𝑘k cycles, while ignoring the order in which the cycles are permuted. The coefficient of znsuperscript𝑧𝑛z^{n} in the corresponding EGF will therefore count the number of ways n𝑛n elements can be decomposed as permutations with cycle lengths in S𝑆S – which is precisely [nk]Ssubscriptmatrix𝑛𝑘𝑆\begin{bmatrix}n\\ k\end{bmatrix}_{S}.

The analysis for {nk}Ssubscriptmatrix𝑛𝑘𝑆\begin{Bmatrix}n\\ k\end{Bmatrix}_{S} roughly follows the one before. However, since the generalized Stirling numbers of the second kind count the number of partitions of n𝑛n into k𝑘k boxes instead of k𝑘k cycles, we apply inner S​E​T𝑆𝐸𝑇SET operators instead of C​Y​C𝐶𝑌𝐶CYC operators.

When considering the EGF of Bn,Ssubscript𝐵𝑛𝑆B_{n,S} we repeat the analysis for [nk]Ssubscriptmatrix𝑛𝑘𝑆\begin{bmatrix}n\\ k\end{bmatrix}_{S}, but now we apply an outer S​E​T𝑆𝐸𝑇SET operator instead of S​E​Tk𝑆𝐸subscript𝑇𝑘SET_{k}, since we care about an arbitrary number of cycles instead of just decompositions into k𝑘k cycles. ∎

When we take S={1,2,3,…}𝑆123…S=\{1,2,3,\ldots\}, we note that ∑s∈Szss!=ex−1subscript𝑠𝑆superscript𝑧𝑠𝑠superscript𝑒𝑥1\sum_{s\in S}\frac{z^{s}}{s!}=e^{x}-1 and we recover the EGF for the classical Bell numbers eex−1superscript𝑒superscript𝑒𝑥1e^{e^{x}-1}. In addition, taking S={1,2,…,m}𝑆12…𝑚S=\{1,2,\ldots,m\} and {m,m+1,m+2,…}𝑚𝑚1𝑚2…\{m,m+1,m+2,\ldots\} recover the generating functions exp⁡(∑i=1mzii!)superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚superscript𝑧𝑖𝑖\exp\left(\sum_{i=1}^{m}\frac{z^{i}}{i!}\right), exp⁡(ex−∑i=0mzii!)superscript𝑒𝑥superscriptsubscript𝑖0𝑚superscript𝑧𝑖𝑖\exp\left(e^{x}-\sum_{i=0}^{m}\frac{z^{i}}{i!}\right), and so on [13, Thm. 4.2, Thm. 5.2, (4.3)].

The last two generating functions show that Bn,Ssubscript𝐵𝑛𝑆B_{n,S} and An,Ssubscript𝐴𝑛𝑆A_{n,S} are special cases of the complete Bell polynomials, which are defined by the generating function

exp⁡(∑n=0∞an​tnn!)=∑n=0∞Bn​(a0,…,an)​tnn!.superscriptsubscript𝑛0subscript𝑎𝑛superscript𝑡𝑛𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑛0subscript𝐵𝑛subscript𝑎0…subscript𝑎𝑛superscript𝑡𝑛𝑛\exp\left(\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}a_{n}\frac{t^{n}}{n!}\right)=\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}B_{n}(a_{0},\ldots,a_{n})\frac{t^{n}}{n!}.

By comparing generating functions, we recover Bn,Ssubscript𝐵𝑛𝑆B_{n,S} through the choice

an={1,n∈S;0,n∉S.subscript𝑎𝑛cases1𝑛𝑆0𝑛𝑆a_{n}=\begin{cases}1,&n\in S;\\ 0,&n\not\in S.\end{cases}

3. Composition sums

Since all of the generating functions in Theorem 1 can be easily represented as the composition of two functions, we can apply the Faà di Bruno formula for higher order derivatives to derive new formulae for An,Ssubscript𝐴𝑛𝑆A_{n,S}, Bn,Ssubscript𝐵𝑛𝑆B_{n,S}, and the generalized Stirling numbers.

Throughout this paper, we will consider compositions of an integer n𝑛n. A composition π𝜋\pi is an ordered tuple of positive integers called parts that add up to n𝑛n – therefore, (1,1,2)112(1,1,2), (1,2,1)121(1,2,1), and (2,1,1)211(2,1,1) all represent different compositions of 444. We denote by 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C} the set of all compositions, by 𝒞nsubscript𝒞𝑛\mathcal{C}_{n} the set of all compositions of n𝑛n, and by |⋅||\thinspace\thinspace\cdot\thinspace\thinspace| the number of parts in a composition. For example, |(1,1,2)|=31123|(1,1,2)|=3. For the composition π∈𝒞n𝜋subscript𝒞𝑛\pi\in\mathcal{C}_{n}, we denote the set of its parts by {πi}subscript𝜋𝑖\{\pi_{i}\}. We also use the multi-index notation gπ:=∏πi∈πgπiassignsubscript𝑔𝜋subscriptproductsubscript𝜋𝑖𝜋subscript𝑔subscript𝜋𝑖g_{\pi}:=\prod_{\pi_{i}\in\pi}g_{\pi_{i}} and π!=∏πi∈ππi!𝜋subscriptproductsubscript𝜋𝑖𝜋subscript𝜋𝑖\pi!=\prod_{\pi_{i}\in\pi}{\pi_{i}!}, which enables us to state a convenient corollary of the classical Faà di Bruno formula:

Proof.

To prove the formula for An,Ssubscript𝐴𝑛𝑆A_{n,S}, apply Theorem 2 with f​(z)=ez𝑓𝑧superscript𝑒𝑧f(z)=e^{z} and g​(z)=∑s∈Szss𝑔𝑧subscript𝑠𝑆superscript𝑧𝑠𝑠g(z)=\sum_{s\in S}\frac{z^{s}}{s}. Therefore,

gπ={1∏πi∈ππi,every part of π is ∈S0,else.subscript𝑔𝜋cases1subscriptproductsubscript𝜋𝑖𝜋subscript𝜋𝑖every part of π is ∈S0elseg_{\pi}=\begin{cases}\frac{1}{\prod_{\pi_{i}\in\pi}{\pi_{i}}},&\text{every part of $\pi$ is $\in S$}\\ 0,&\text{else}\end{cases}.

∑π∈𝒞nf|π|​gπ=∑π∈𝒞n1|π|!​∏πi∈ππi​𝟙πi∈S=∑π∈𝒞nπi∈S1|π|!​∏πi∈ππi,subscript𝜋subscript𝒞𝑛subscript𝑓𝜋subscript𝑔𝜋subscript𝜋subscript𝒞𝑛1𝜋subscriptproductsubscript𝜋𝑖𝜋subscript𝜋𝑖subscript1subscript𝜋𝑖𝑆subscript𝜋subscript𝒞𝑛subscript𝜋𝑖𝑆1𝜋subscriptproductsubscript𝜋𝑖𝜋subscript𝜋𝑖\sum_{\pi\in\mathcal{C}_{n}}f_{|\pi|}g_{\pi}=\sum_{\pi\in\mathcal{C}_{n}}\frac{1}{|\pi|!\prod_{\pi_{i}\in\pi}{\pi_{i}}}\mathbbm{1}_{\pi_{i}\in S}=\sum_{\begin{subarray}{c}\pi\in\mathcal{C}_{n}\\ \pi_{i}\in S\end{subarray}}\frac{1}{|\pi|!\prod_{\pi_{i}\in\pi}{\pi_{i}}},

where the restriction on the parts of S𝑆S is transferred to the summation. Comparing coefficients completes the proof. The formula for Bn,Ssubscript𝐵𝑛𝑆B_{n,S} is proven identically with g​(z)=∑s∈Szss!𝑔𝑧subscript𝑠𝑆superscript𝑧𝑠𝑠g(z)=\sum_{s\in S}\frac{z^{s}}{s!} instead.

To prove the formula for [nk]Ssubscriptmatrix𝑛𝑘𝑆\begin{bmatrix}n\\ k\end{bmatrix}_{S}, apply Theorem 2 with f​(z)=zkk!𝑓𝑧superscript𝑧𝑘𝑘f(z)=\frac{z^{k}}{k!} and g​(z)=∑s∈Szss𝑔𝑧subscript𝑠𝑆superscript𝑧𝑠𝑠g(z)=\sum_{s\in S}\frac{z^{s}}{s}. Now we have the piecewise definition

f|π|={1|π|!,|π|=k0,else.subscript𝑓𝜋cases1𝜋𝜋𝑘0elsef_{|\pi|}=\begin{cases}\frac{1}{|\pi|!},&|\pi|=k\\ 0,&\text{else}\end{cases}.

We can then simplify the composition sum since

∑π∈𝒞nf|π|​gπ=∑π∈𝒞nπi∈S1|π|!​∏πi∈ππi​𝟙|π|=k=∑π∈𝒞nπi∈S|π|=k1|π|!​∏πi∈ππi.subscript𝜋subscript𝒞𝑛subscript𝑓𝜋subscript𝑔𝜋subscript𝜋subscript𝒞𝑛subscript𝜋𝑖𝑆1𝜋subscriptproductsubscript𝜋𝑖𝜋subscript𝜋𝑖subscript1𝜋𝑘subscript𝜋subscript𝒞𝑛subscript𝜋𝑖𝑆𝜋𝑘1𝜋subscriptproductsubscript𝜋𝑖𝜋subscript𝜋𝑖\sum_{\pi\in\mathcal{C}_{n}}f_{|\pi|}g_{\pi}=\sum_{\begin{subarray}{c}\pi\in\mathcal{C}_{n}\\ \pi_{i}\in S\end{subarray}}\frac{1}{|\pi|!\prod_{\pi_{i}\in\pi}{\pi_{i}}}\mathbbm{1}_{|\pi|=k}=\sum_{\begin{subarray}{c}\pi\in\mathcal{C}_{n}\\ \pi_{i}\in S\\ |\pi|=k\end{subarray}}\frac{1}{|\pi|!\prod_{\pi_{i}\in\pi}{\pi_{i}}}.

The analysis for {nk}Ssubscriptmatrix𝑛𝑘𝑆\begin{Bmatrix}n\\ k\end{Bmatrix}_{S} proceeds identically, but with g​(z)=∑s∈Szss!𝑔𝑧subscript𝑠𝑆superscript𝑧𝑠𝑠g(z)=\sum_{s\in S}\frac{z^{s}}{s!} instead. ∎

In the case S=ℤ≥1𝑆subscriptℤabsent1S=\mathbb{Z}_{\geq 1}, we recover known expressions for the classic Stirling and Bell numbers. We can simply leave the restriction πi∈Ssubscript𝜋𝑖𝑆\pi_{i}\in S off the summation, since we’re now allowing all positive parts.

An avenue for further research is to find a combinatorial proof of any of the above identities. The appearance of a composition sum is not coincidental; it has a very natural connection to all of these numbers. Take the generalized Bell numbers as an example: we care about how we can partition n𝑛n elements into blocks, where each block has a size found in S𝑆S. This is precisely an unordered composition of n𝑛n with each part in S𝑆S. When passing from compositions to partitions we are overcounting in some way which is accounted for by the composition sum.

Corollary 4.

We have the inequalities

[nk]S≥{nk}Ssubscriptmatrix𝑛𝑘𝑆subscriptmatrix𝑛𝑘𝑆\begin{bmatrix}n\\ k\end{bmatrix}_{S}\geq\begin{Bmatrix}n\\ k\end{Bmatrix}_{S}

and

An,S≥Bn,S.subscript𝐴𝑛𝑆subscript𝐵𝑛𝑆A_{n,S}\geq B_{n,S}.
Proof.

For π∈𝒞n𝜋subscript𝒞𝑛\pi\in\mathcal{C}_{n}, we have π!≥∏πi∈ππi𝜋subscriptproductsubscript𝜋𝑖𝜋subscript𝜋𝑖\pi!\geq\prod_{\pi_{i}\in\pi}\pi_{i} with equality if and only if πi=1subscript𝜋𝑖1\pi_{i}=1 – that is, π=(1,1,…,1)𝜋11…1\pi=(1,1,\ldots,1). Looking at the composition sum expressions in Theorem 3, this inequality will therefore be satisfied termwise. ∎

4. Recurrences

We can then derive several general recurrences satisfied by these numbers, the first two of which generalize [13, Thm. 4.2, Thm. 5.2]. All of the following identities also have combinatorial and umbral proofs; however, the generating function approach appears to be the most concise for the following simple identities. We also note that since all four types considered in this work are specializations of the Bell polynomials, several of the recurrences described here are specializations of recurrences for the Bell polynomials.

Theorem 5.

We have the recurrences

An+1,S=∑s∈Sn!(n−s+1)!​An−s+1,S,subscript𝐴𝑛1𝑆subscript𝑠𝑆𝑛𝑛𝑠1subscript𝐴𝑛𝑠1𝑆A_{n+1,S}=\sum_{s\in S}\frac{n!}{(n-s+1)!}A_{n-s+1,S},
Bn+1,S=∑s∈S(ns−1)​Bn−s+1,S,subscript𝐵𝑛1𝑆subscript𝑠𝑆binomial𝑛𝑠1subscript𝐵𝑛𝑠1𝑆B_{n+1,S}=\sum_{s\in S}\binom{n}{s-1}B_{n-s+1,S},
[n+1k]S=∑s∈Sn!(n−j+1)!​[n−s+1k−1]S,subscriptmatrix𝑛1𝑘𝑆subscript𝑠𝑆𝑛𝑛𝑗1subscriptmatrix𝑛𝑠1𝑘1𝑆\begin{bmatrix}n+1\\ k\end{bmatrix}_{S}=\sum_{s\in S}\frac{n!}{(n-j+1)!}\begin{bmatrix}n-s+1\\ k-1\end{bmatrix}_{S},

Proof.

For concreteness we work only with the generalized Bell numbers. Taking a derivative of the generating function from Theorem 1, ∑n=0∞Bn,S​znn!=exp⁡(∑s∈Szss!),superscriptsubscript𝑛0subscript𝐵𝑛𝑆superscript𝑧𝑛𝑛subscript𝑠𝑆superscript𝑧𝑠𝑠\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}B_{n,S}\frac{z^{n}}{n!}=\exp\left(\sum_{s\in S}\frac{z^{s}}{s!}\right), gives

∑n=0∞Bn+1,S​znn!=(∑s∈Szs−1(s−1)!)​exp⁡(∑s∈Szss!)=(∑s∈Szs−1(s−1)!)​(∑n=0∞Bn,S​znn!).superscriptsubscript𝑛0subscript𝐵𝑛1𝑆superscript𝑧𝑛𝑛subscript𝑠𝑆superscript𝑧𝑠1𝑠1subscript𝑠𝑆superscript𝑧𝑠𝑠subscript𝑠𝑆superscript𝑧𝑠1𝑠1superscriptsubscript𝑛0subscript𝐵𝑛𝑆superscript𝑧𝑛𝑛\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}B_{n+1,S}\frac{z^{n}}{n!}=\left(\sum_{s\in S}\frac{z^{s-1}}{(s-1)!}\right)\exp\left(\sum_{s\in S}\frac{z^{s}}{s!}\right)=\left(\sum_{s\in S}\frac{z^{s-1}}{(s-1)!}\right)\left(\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}B_{n,S}\frac{z^{n}}{n!}\right).

Taking a Cauchy product and comparing coefficients completes the proof. The other proofs follow exactly the same lines, and follow from taking derivatives and then comparing coefficients. ∎

We also present a combinatorial proof of the second recurrence; the rest follow from similar reasoning. Start with n+1𝑛1n+1 elements and distinguish the first one. We can partition these n+1𝑛1n+1 elements in Bn+1,Ssubscript𝐵𝑛1𝑆B_{n+1,S} ways. However, we can also add s−1𝑠1s-1 elements to the first one, for any cardinality index s∈S𝑠𝑆s\in S. There are (ns−1)binomial𝑛𝑠1\binom{n}{s-1} ways to pick these s−1𝑠1s-1 elements, and then Bn−(s−1),Ssubscript𝐵𝑛𝑠1𝑆B_{n-(s-1),S} ways to partition the rest. Summing over s𝑠s completes the proof.

We can also derive lacunary recurrences which take far fewer terms to compute. In particular, the formulae below have σ𝜎\sigma completely free so they can take arbitrarily few terms to compute Bn,S∪σsubscript𝐵𝑛𝑆𝜎B_{n,S\cup\sigma} if σ𝜎\sigma is large enough relative to n𝑛n. We also note that these recover [13, Thm 4.1, Thm. 4.6] in the case S={1,2,…,m−1}𝑆12…𝑚1S=\{1,2,\ldots,m-1\} (or S={1,2,…,m}𝑆12…𝑚S=\{1,2,\ldots,m\} for Theorem 4.6) and σ=m𝜎𝑚\sigma=m, where it was derived combinatorially.

Theorem 6.

We can also prove a similar theorem about An,Ssubscript𝐴𝑛𝑆A_{n,S} using exactly the same reasoning, special cases of which are [13, Thm. 5.1, Thm. 5.5].

Theorem 7.

If σ∉S𝜎𝑆\sigma\not\in S, we have the recurrence

We can also prove other properties based on splitting S𝑆S, generalizing [13, Thm. 4.7]. We note that (nn1,n2,…)binomial𝑛subscript𝑛1subscript𝑛2…\binom{n}{n_{1},n_{2},\ldots} is the multinomial coefficient n!n1!​n2!​⋯𝑛subscript𝑛1subscript𝑛2⋯\frac{n!}{n_{1}!n_{2}!\cdots}, and 𝒞nsubscript𝒞𝑛\mathcal{C}_{n} in the set of compositions of n𝑛n, described in the next section.

Theorem 8.

Let S=∪iSi𝑆subscript𝑖subscript𝑆𝑖S=\cup_{i}S_{i}, where Si∩Sj=∅subscript𝑆𝑖subscript𝑆𝑗S_{i}\cap S_{j}=\emptyset for i≠j𝑖𝑗i\neq j, so that the sets {Si}subscript𝑆𝑖\{S_{i}\} partition S𝑆S. Then

∑n=0∞Bn,S​znn!=exp⁡(∑s∈Szss!)=∏iexp⁡(∑s∈Sizss!)=∏i∑n=0∞Bn,S1​znn!.superscriptsubscript𝑛0subscript𝐵𝑛𝑆superscript𝑧𝑛𝑛subscript𝑠𝑆superscript𝑧𝑠𝑠subscriptproduct𝑖subscript𝑠subscript𝑆𝑖superscript𝑧𝑠𝑠subscriptproduct𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑛0subscript𝐵𝑛subscript𝑆1superscript𝑧𝑛𝑛\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}B_{n,S}\frac{z^{n}}{n!}=\exp\left(\sum_{s\in S}\frac{z^{s}}{s!}\right)=\prod_{i}\exp\left(\sum_{s\in S_{i}}\frac{z^{s}}{s!}\right)=\prod_{i}\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}B_{n,S_{1}}\frac{z^{n}}{n!}.

Computing coefficients of znsuperscript𝑧𝑛z^{n} in the resulting product completes the proof. ∎

Corollary 9.

Let S=∪iSi𝑆subscript𝑖subscript𝑆𝑖S=\cup_{i}S_{i}, where Si∩Sj=∅subscript𝑆𝑖subscript𝑆𝑗S_{i}\cap S_{j}=\emptyset for i≠j𝑖𝑗i\neq j so that the sets {Si}subscript𝑆𝑖\{S_{i}\} partition S𝑆S, and take p𝑝p a prime. Then

Bp,S≡∑iBp,Si(modp),subscript𝐵𝑝𝑆annotatedsubscript𝑖subscript𝐵𝑝subscript𝑆𝑖pmod𝑝B_{p,S}\equiv\sum_{i}B_{p,S_{i}}\pmod{p},

and

Ap,S≡∑iAp,Si(modp).subscript𝐴𝑝𝑆annotatedsubscript𝑖subscript𝐴𝑝subscript𝑆𝑖pmod𝑝A_{p,S}\equiv\sum_{i}A_{p,S_{i}}\pmod{p}.
Proof.

If a composition π𝜋\pi has each part strictly smaller than n𝑛n then (pπ1,π2,…)≡0(modp)binomial𝑝subscript𝜋1subscript𝜋2…annotated0pmod𝑝\binom{p}{\pi_{1},\pi_{2},\ldots}\equiv 0\pmod{p} since (pπ1,π2,…)=p!π1!,π2!,…binomial𝑝subscript𝜋1subscript𝜋2…𝑝subscript𝜋1subscript𝜋2…\binom{p}{\pi_{1},\pi_{2},\ldots}=\frac{p!}{\pi_{1}!,\pi_{2}!,\ldots} has a power of p𝑝p in the numerator which is not canceled by one in the denominator. Every term in the summation then vanishes modulo p𝑝p, save for those of the form π=(0,0,…,πi=p,…,0)\pi=(0,0,\ldots,\pi_{i}=p,\ldots,0). Taking into account the initial values A0,Sj=B0,Sj=1subscript𝐴0subscript𝑆𝑗subscript𝐵0subscript𝑆𝑗1A_{0,S_{j}}=B_{0,S_{j}}=1 for those compositions completes the proof. ∎

We now discuss Spivey’s formula [17],

Bn+m=∑k=0n∑j=0mjn−k​{mj}​(nk)​Bk.subscript𝐵𝑛𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑘0𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑗0𝑚superscript𝑗𝑛𝑘matrix𝑚𝑗binomial𝑛𝑘subscript𝐵𝑘B_{n+m}=\sum_{k=0}^{n}\sum_{j=0}^{m}j^{n-k}\begin{Bmatrix}m\\ j\end{Bmatrix}\binom{n}{k}B_{k}.

The cases n=0𝑛0n=0 and m=1𝑚1m=1 are

Bm=∑j=0m{mj}subscript𝐵𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑗0𝑚matrix𝑚𝑗B_{m}=\sum_{j=0}^{m}\begin{Bmatrix}m\\ j\end{Bmatrix}

Bn+1=∑k=0n(nk)​Bk,subscript𝐵𝑛1superscriptsubscript𝑘0𝑛binomial𝑛𝑘subscript𝐵𝑘B_{n+1}=\sum_{k=0}^{n}\binom{n}{k}B_{k},

which are the two most basic recurrences satisfied by the Bell numbers. These have the analogs

Bm,S=∑j=0m{mj}Ssubscript𝐵𝑚𝑆superscriptsubscript𝑗0𝑚subscriptmatrix𝑚𝑗𝑆B_{m,S}=\sum_{j=0}^{m}\begin{Bmatrix}m\\ j\end{Bmatrix}_{S}

and (from Theorem 5)

Bn+1,S=∑s∈S(ns−1)​Bn−s+1,S,subscript𝐵𝑛1𝑆subscript𝑠𝑆binomial𝑛𝑠1subscript𝐵𝑛𝑠1𝑆B_{n+1,S}=\sum_{s\in S}\binom{n}{s-1}B_{n-s+1,S},

suggesting the existence of a Spivey-type formula for the generalized Bell numbers. However, this analog has been particularly difficult to find.

5. Umbral approach

The goal of umbral calculus is to simplify the proof of many identities by turning manipulation of sequences into manipulations of moments; this effectively turns questions about subscripts into questions about superscripts. We can do this if, for a sequence {an},subscript𝑎𝑛\{a_{n}\}, we can find a measure μ𝜇\mu such that

an=∫xn​𝑑μ​(x).subscript𝑎𝑛superscript𝑥𝑛differential-d𝜇𝑥a_{n}=\int x^{n}d\mu\left(x\right).

Ideally, μ𝜇\mu would be a probability measure, i.e. a positive measure with unit total integral (which implies a0=1subscript𝑎01a_{0}=1), but it is important to note that umbral calculus does not require that μ𝜇\mu is a probability measure. However, not every sequence of real numbers {an}subscript𝑎𝑛\{a_{n}\} can be a (probabilistic) moment sequence. Basic probabilistic results such as Var​(𝒜)=𝔼​𝒜2−(𝔼​𝒜)2≥0Var𝒜𝔼superscript𝒜2superscript𝔼𝒜20\text{Var}(\mathcal{A})=\mathbb{E}\mathcal{A}^{2}-(\mathbb{E}\mathcal{A})^{2}\geq 0 impose strong constraints on the sequence {an}.subscript𝑎𝑛\{a_{n}\}. For example, we cannot have the moment sequence {a1=1,a2=0}formulae-sequencesubscript𝑎11subscript𝑎20\{a_{1}=1,a_{2}=0\} since this yields a negative variance.

However, if we are given a sequence that can be written as the moments of a measure μ𝜇\mu, we can then rewrite identities on sequences as identities on the moments of their underlying random variables. For a concrete example, consider the expression

(5.1) ∑k=0n(nk)​ak​an−k=∑k=0n(nk)​𝔼​𝒜1k​𝔼​𝒜2n−k=𝔼​∑k=0n(nk)​𝒜1k​𝒜2n−k=𝔼​(𝒜1+𝒜2)n,superscriptsubscript𝑘0𝑛binomial𝑛𝑘subscript𝑎𝑘subscript𝑎𝑛𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑘0𝑛binomial𝑛𝑘𝔼superscriptsubscript𝒜1𝑘𝔼superscriptsubscript𝒜2𝑛𝑘𝔼superscriptsubscript𝑘0𝑛binomial𝑛𝑘superscriptsubscript𝒜1𝑘superscriptsubscript𝒜2𝑛𝑘𝔼superscriptsubscript𝒜1subscript𝒜2𝑛\sum_{k=0}^{n}\binom{n}{k}a_{k}a_{n-k}=\sum_{k=0}^{n}\binom{n}{k}\mathbb{E}\mathcal{A}_{1}^{k}\mathbb{E}\mathcal{A}_{2}^{n-k}=\mathbb{E}\sum_{k=0}^{n}\binom{n}{k}\mathcal{A}_{1}^{k}\mathcal{A}_{2}^{n-k}=\mathbb{E}(\mathcal{A}_{1}+\mathcal{A}_{2})^{n},

where 𝒜1subscript𝒜1\mathcal{A}_{1} and 𝒜2subscript𝒜2\mathcal{A}_{2} are two independent random variables. Now, based on the moments of the distribution 𝒜1+𝒜2subscript𝒜1subscript𝒜2\mathcal{A}_{1}+\mathcal{A}_{2}, we obtain a nontrivial identity for the sequence {an}subscript𝑎𝑛\{a_{n}\}. For example, take 𝒜1∼Γp1similar-tosubscript𝒜1subscriptΓsubscript𝑝1\mathcal{A}_{1}\sim\Gamma_{p_{1}} and 𝒜2∼Γp2similar-tosubscript𝒜2subscriptΓsubscript𝑝2\mathcal{A}_{2}\sim\Gamma_{p_{2}} where ∼similar-to\sim denotes equality of distributiions. We have let ΓpsubscriptΓ𝑝\Gamma_{p} denote a gamma-distributed random variable with density

1Γ​(p)​e−x​xp−1,1Γ𝑝superscript𝑒𝑥superscript𝑥𝑝1\frac{1}{\Gamma\left(p\right)}e^{-x}x^{p-1},

so that 𝒜1+𝒜2∼Γ​(p1+p2).similar-tosubscript𝒜1subscript𝒜2Γsubscript𝑝1subscript𝑝2\mathcal{A}_{1}+\mathcal{A}_{2}\sim\Gamma\left(p_{1}+p_{2}\right). Since the moments of a Gamma random variable are the Pochhammer symbols

𝔼​Γpk=(p)k:=∏i=0k−1(p+i),𝔼superscriptsubscriptΓ𝑝𝑘subscript𝑝𝑘assignsuperscriptsubscriptproduct𝑖0𝑘1𝑝𝑖\mathbb{E}\Gamma_{p}^{k}=\left(p\right)_{k}:=\prod_{i=0}^{k-1}(p+i),

identity (5.1) translates into

(5.2) ∑k=0n(nk)​(p1)k​(p2)n−k=(p1+p2)n,superscriptsubscript𝑘0𝑛binomial𝑛𝑘subscriptsubscript𝑝1𝑘subscriptsubscript𝑝2𝑛𝑘subscriptsubscript𝑝1subscript𝑝2𝑛\sum_{k=0}^{n}\binom{n}{k}\left(p_{1}\right)_{k}\left(p_{2}\right)_{n-k}=\left(p_{1}+p_{2}\right)_{n},

which is nothing but the Chu-Vandermonde identity.

As can be seen from this example, the keys ideas at play here are the linearity of the expectation and the fact that 𝔼​𝒜1​𝒜2=𝔼​𝒜1×𝔼​𝒜2𝔼subscript𝒜1subscript𝒜2𝔼subscript𝒜1𝔼subscript𝒜2\mathbb{E}\mathcal{A}_{1}\mathcal{A}_{2}=\mathbb{E}\mathcal{A}_{1}\times\mathbb{E}\mathcal{A}_{2} for independent random variables. This allows us to transform questions involving the sequence {an}subscript𝑎𝑛\{a_{n}\}, which a priori has no structure, into questions about moments of a random variable, which behave like powers. For more background into umbral approaches, consult [8, 16].

After some annoying reverse engineering, we can explicitly construct a random variable which has the complete Bell polynomials as a moment sequence, showing that the Bell polynomials behave umbrally. They are in fact special cases of a Sheffer sequence, which is one of the most general polynomial sequences which satisfies umbral relations. The construction is quite involved, but allows us to systematize the derivation of identities for the Bell polynomials through umbral methods. In the next section, we will specialize this analysis to obtain results for the generalized Bell and Stirling numbers.

We first describe a stable random variable, which is a random variable X𝑋X such that there exist constants cnsubscript𝑐𝑛c_{n} and dnsubscript𝑑𝑛d_{n} so that

X1+X2+…+Xn∼cn​X+dn,similar-tosubscript𝑋1subscript𝑋2…subscript𝑋𝑛subscript𝑐𝑛𝑋subscript𝑑𝑛X_{1}+X_{2}+\ldots+X_{n}\sim c_{n}X+d_{n},

where the {Xi}subscript𝑋𝑖\{X_{i}\} are independent and identically distributed copies of X𝑋X. It is a general result [15, Chapter 1] that a variable is stable if and only if it is equal to a​Z+b𝑎𝑍𝑏aZ+b, where Z𝑍Z has characteristic function

𝔼​exp⁡(i​u​Z)={exp⁡(−|u|α​(1−i​β​sign​(u)​tan⁡(12​α​π)))α≠1,exp⁡(−|u|​(1+i​β​sign​(u)​2π​log⁡(u)))α=1.𝔼𝑖𝑢𝑍casessuperscript𝑢𝛼1𝑖𝛽sign𝑢12𝛼𝜋𝛼1𝑢1𝑖𝛽sign𝑢2𝜋𝑢𝛼1\mathbb{E}\exp\left(iuZ\right)=\begin{cases}\exp\left(-|u|^{\alpha}\left(1-i\beta\thinspace\text{sign}(u)\tan\left(\frac{1}{2}\alpha\pi\right)\right)\right)\thinspace\thinspace\thinspace&\alpha\neq 1,\\ \exp\left(-|u|\left(1+i\beta\thinspace\text{sign}(u)\frac{2}{\pi}\log\left(u\right)\right)\right)\thinspace\thinspace\thinspace&\alpha=1.\end{cases}

This is a two parameter distribution under the restrictions 0<α≤20𝛼20<\alpha\leq 2 and −1≤β≤11𝛽1-1\leq\beta\leq 1.

We introduce the symmetric α𝛼\alpha-stable distribution Sαsubscript𝑆𝛼S_{\alpha}, which is the case β=0𝛽0\beta=0. It is symmetric around the origin and has moment generating function 𝔼​eu​𝒮α=euα.𝔼superscript𝑒𝑢subscript𝒮𝛼superscript𝑒superscript𝑢𝛼\mathbb{E}e^{u\mathcal{S}_{\alpha}}=e^{u^{{\alpha}}}. Note that we still have the very strict requirement 0<α≤20𝛼20<\alpha\leq 2, which is why we cannot assign 𝒜j∼Sjsimilar-tosubscript𝒜𝑗subscript𝑆𝑗\mathcal{A}_{j}\sim S_{j} in the results that follow.

Proof.

𝔼​et​𝒜=∏j=0∞𝔼​eaj1j​(j!)−1j​t​𝒜j=∏j=0∞eaj​tjj!=exp⁡(∑j=0∞aj​tjj!)=∑j=0∞Bj​(a0,…,an)​tjj!,𝔼superscript𝑒𝑡𝒜superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑗0𝔼superscript𝑒superscriptsubscript𝑎𝑗1𝑗superscript𝑗1𝑗𝑡subscript𝒜𝑗superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑗0superscript𝑒subscript𝑎𝑗superscript𝑡𝑗𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑗0subscript𝑎𝑗superscript𝑡𝑗𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑗0subscript𝐵𝑗subscript𝑎0…subscript𝑎𝑛superscript𝑡𝑗𝑗\mathbb{E}e^{t\mathcal{A}}=\prod_{j=0}^{\infty}\mathbb{E}e^{a_{j}^{\frac{1}{j}}\left(j!\right)^{-\frac{1}{j}}t\mathcal{A}_{j}}=\prod_{j=0}^{\infty}e^{a_{j}\frac{t^{j}}{j!}}=\exp\left(\sum_{j=0}^{\infty}a_{j}\frac{t^{j}}{j!}\right)=\sum_{j=0}^{\infty}B_{j}(a_{0},\ldots,a_{n})\frac{t^{j}}{j!},

which completes the proof. ∎

We can then exploit this representation to prove umbral identities. Most of the recurrence relations proven earlier also have simple umbral proofs. We can also construct a conjugate variable for 𝒜jsubscript𝒜𝑗\mathcal{A}_{j} – a random variable 𝒜~jsubscript~𝒜𝑗\tilde{\mathcal{A}}_{j} that is independent of 𝒜jsubscript𝒜𝑗\mathcal{A}_{j} and satisfies

𝔼​(𝒜j+𝒜~j)n=δn​0,𝔼superscriptsubscript𝒜𝑗subscript~𝒜𝑗𝑛subscript𝛿𝑛0\mathbb{E}\left(\mathcal{A}_{j}+\tilde{\mathcal{A}}_{j}\right)^{n}=\delta_{n0},

which will be extremely useful in generating umbral identities. Here, δi​jsubscript𝛿𝑖𝑗\delta_{ij} is the Kronecker delta function.

Theorem 11.

Let 𝒜~j∼exp⁡(π​ij)​𝒜j;similar-tosubscript~𝒜𝑗𝜋𝑖𝑗subscript𝒜𝑗\tilde{\mathcal{A}}_{j}\sim\exp\left({\frac{\pi i}{j}}\right)\mathcal{A}_{j}; then 𝒜~jsubscript~𝒜𝑗\tilde{\mathcal{A}}_{j} is conjugate to 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}. Moreover,

𝒜~∼∑j=0∞aj1j​(j!)−1j​𝒜~j,similar-to~𝒜superscriptsubscript𝑗0superscriptsubscript𝑎𝑗1𝑗superscript𝑗1𝑗subscript~𝒜𝑗\tilde{\mathcal{A}}\sim\sum_{j=0}^{\infty}a_{j}^{\frac{1}{j}}(j!)^{-\frac{1}{j}}\tilde{\mathcal{A}}_{j},

where the {𝒜~j}subscript~𝒜𝑗\{\tilde{\mathcal{A}}_{j}\} are independent random variables, is conjugate to 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}. Hence,

𝔼​(𝒜+𝒜~)n=δn​0.𝔼superscript𝒜~𝒜𝑛subscript𝛿𝑛0\mathbb{E}(\mathcal{A}+\tilde{\mathcal{A}})^{n}=\delta_{n0}.
Proof.

Two independent random variables 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X} and 𝒴𝒴\mathcal{Y} are conjugate if and only if 𝔼​et​𝒳​et​𝒴=1𝔼superscript𝑒𝑡𝒳superscript𝑒𝑡𝒴1\mathbb{E}e^{t\mathcal{X}}e^{t\mathcal{Y}}=1; we can show this by expanding this the expectation as a series. Therefore,

𝔼​et​𝒳​et​𝒴=∑n=0∞tnn!​𝔼​(𝒳+𝒴)n=1,𝔼superscript𝑒𝑡𝒳superscript𝑒𝑡𝒴superscriptsubscript𝑛0superscript𝑡𝑛𝑛𝔼superscript𝒳𝒴𝑛1\mathbb{E}e^{t\mathcal{X}}e^{t\mathcal{Y}}=\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}\frac{t^{n}}{n!}\mathbb{E}(\mathcal{X}+\mathcal{{Y}})^{n}=1,

and E​(𝒳+𝒴)n=δn​0𝐸superscript𝒳𝒴𝑛subscript𝛿𝑛0E(\mathcal{X}+\mathcal{{Y}})^{n}=\delta_{n0}.

𝒜jsubscript𝒜𝑗\mathcal{A}_{j} and 𝒜~jsubscript~𝒜𝑗\tilde{\mathcal{A}}_{j} can be seen as conjugate after manually comparing moment generating functions: A~jsubscript~𝐴𝑗\tilde{A}_{j} has moments

𝔼​𝒜~jn={0n≢0(modj)q​j!q!​(−1)qn=q​j,𝔼superscriptsubscript~𝒜𝑗𝑛cases0not-equivalent-to𝑛annotated0pmod𝑗𝑞𝑗𝑞superscript1𝑞𝑛𝑞𝑗\mathbb{E}\tilde{\mathcal{A}}_{j}^{n}=\begin{cases}0&n\not\equiv 0\pmod{j}\\ \frac{qj!}{q!}(-1)^{q}&n=qj\end{cases},

so

𝔼​et​𝒜~j=∑n=0∞𝔼​𝒜~jn​tnn!=∑n=0∞tj​nj​n!​j​n!n!​(−1)n=e−tj.𝔼superscript𝑒𝑡subscript~𝒜𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑛0𝔼superscriptsubscript~𝒜𝑗𝑛superscript𝑡𝑛𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑛0superscript𝑡𝑗𝑛𝑗𝑛𝑗𝑛𝑛superscript1𝑛superscript𝑒superscript𝑡𝑗\mathbb{E}e^{t\tilde{\mathcal{A}}_{j}}=\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}\mathbb{E}\tilde{\mathcal{A}}_{j}^{n}\frac{t^{n}}{n!}=\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}\frac{t^{jn}}{jn!}\frac{{jn}!}{n!}(-1)^{n}=e^{-t^{j}}.

Due to the independence of the {𝒜~j}subscript~𝒜𝑗\{\tilde{\mathcal{A}}_{j}\}, we then compute

𝔼​et​𝒜~=∏j=0∞𝔼​eaj1j​(j!)−1j​t​𝒜~j=∏j=0∞e−aj​tjj!=exp⁡(−∑j=0∞aj​tjj!).𝔼superscript𝑒𝑡~𝒜superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑗0𝔼superscript𝑒superscriptsubscript𝑎𝑗1𝑗superscript𝑗1𝑗𝑡subscript~𝒜𝑗superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑗0superscript𝑒subscript𝑎𝑗superscript𝑡𝑗𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑗0subscript𝑎𝑗superscript𝑡𝑗𝑗\mathbb{E}e^{t\tilde{\mathcal{A}}}=\prod_{j=0}^{\infty}\mathbb{E}e^{a_{j}^{\frac{1}{j}}\left(j!\right)^{-\frac{1}{j}}t\tilde{\mathcal{A}}_{j}}=\prod_{j=0}^{\infty}e^{-a_{j}\frac{t^{j}}{j!}}=\exp\left(-\sum_{j=0}^{\infty}a_{j}\frac{t^{j}}{j!}\right).

Using this expression, 𝔼​et​𝒜​et​𝒜~=1𝔼superscript𝑒𝑡𝒜superscript𝑒𝑡~𝒜1\mathbb{E}e^{t\mathcal{A}}e^{t\tilde{\mathcal{A}}}=1 and we are done. ∎

While an umbral approach simply requires us to verify that a sequence is a moment sequence, by explicitly constructing the relevant random variable we can obtain a slew of new expression for the Bell and Stirling numbers. By specializing Theorem 10 to the Bell and factorial numbers, we have the following important corollaries:

Corollary 12.

If {𝒜j}subscript𝒜𝑗\{\mathcal{A}_{j}\} is a set of independent random variables, as given in Theorem 10, then for

𝒜∼∑s∈S(s!)−1s​𝒜s,similar-to𝒜subscript𝑠𝑆superscript𝑠1𝑠subscript𝒜𝑠\mathcal{A}\sim\sum_{s\in S}\left(s!\right)^{-\frac{1}{s}}\mathcal{A}_{s},

we have

𝔼​𝒜n=Bn,S.𝔼superscript𝒜𝑛subscript𝐵𝑛𝑆\mathbb{E}\mathcal{A}^{n}=B_{n,S}.
Corollary 13.

Let

𝒜∼∑s∈Ss−1s​𝒜s.similar-to𝒜subscript𝑠𝑆superscript𝑠1𝑠subscript𝒜𝑠\mathcal{A}\sim\sum_{s\in S}s^{-\frac{1}{s}}\mathcal{A}_{s}.

Then

𝔼​𝒜n=An,S.𝔼superscript𝒜𝑛subscript𝐴𝑛𝑆\mathbb{E}\mathcal{A}^{n}=A_{n,S}.

6. Next steps

These results suggest the study of other types of restricted Bell numbers. An example would be “even" or “odd" Bell numbers, which arise from taking Se:={2,4,6,…}assignsubscript𝑆𝑒246…S_{e}:=\{2,4,6,\ldots\} and So:={1,3,5,…}assignsubscript𝑆𝑜135…S_{o}:=\{1,3,5,\ldots\}. The even and odd Bell numbers that count the number of partitions of n𝑛n into blocks of even (respectively, odd) size. While all of the above theorems apply to the even and odd Bell numbers, we also note that we have results like Bn=∑k=0n(nk)​Bk,Se​Bn−k,Sosubscript𝐵𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑘0𝑛binomial𝑛𝑘subscript𝐵𝑘subscript𝑆𝑒subscript𝐵𝑛𝑘subscript𝑆𝑜B_{n}=\sum_{k=0}^{n}\binom{n}{k}B_{k,S_{e}}B_{n-k,S_{o}}. This means that further information about the even and odd Bell numbers could yield new information about the classical case. Another interesting approach would be to compute the valuations of these dissections with respect to small primes, and how that relates to the p𝑝p-adic valuation of the Bell numbers. We already initiated work in this direction with Corollary 9.

In fact, work has already been done on the dissection of Bnsubscript𝐵𝑛B_{n}, depending on whether it splits n𝑛n into an even or odd number of blocks - the so called ‘complementary Bell numbers’. This is the subject of Wilf’s Conjecture, which asks whether the two values are ever equal [5]. However, our methods are more suited towards dissecting Bnsubscript𝐵𝑛B_{n} into whether is splits n𝑛n into blocks of even or odd size.

In any case, our generating functions provide refinements of their classical counterparts, which enables us to dissect the classical case in various ways. For instance, the rank of a partition naturally dissects partitions into residues classes modulo 555. It provides a refinement of the classical partition counting function p​(n)𝑝𝑛p(n). Analogously, we could consider Bell and Stirling numbers consisting of box sizes modulo a prime p𝑝p. When p=2𝑝2p=2 we are led to the even and odd Bell numbers previously discussed. However, we could consider the sets Sp(1)={1,p+1,2​p+1,…}superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑝11𝑝12𝑝1…S_{p}^{(1)}=\{1,p+1,2p+1,\ldots\}, Sp(2)={2,p+2,p+2,…}superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑝22𝑝2𝑝2…S_{p}^{(2)}=\{2,p+2,p+2,\ldots\}, and more generally Sp(i)={i,p+i,2​p+i,…}superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑝𝑖𝑖𝑝𝑖2𝑝𝑖…S_{p}^{(i)}=\{i,p+i,2p+i,\ldots\} for 1≤i≤p1𝑖𝑝1\leq i\leq p. Then ℤ≥1=∪i=1pSp(i)subscriptℤabsent1superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑝superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑝𝑖\mathbb{Z}_{\geq 1}=\cup_{i=1}^{p}S_{p}^{(i)} and we recover the classical case as the multinomial sum

Bn=∑π∈𝒞n(nπ1,π2,…)​Bπ1,Sp(1)​Bπ2,Sp(2)​⋯.subscript𝐵𝑛subscript𝜋subscript𝒞𝑛binomial𝑛subscript𝜋1subscript𝜋2…subscript𝐵subscript𝜋1superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑝1subscript𝐵subscript𝜋2superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑝2⋯B_{n}=\sum_{\pi\in\mathcal{C}_{n}}\binom{n}{\pi_{1},\pi_{2},\ldots}B_{\pi_{1},S_{p}^{(1)}}B_{\pi_{2},S_{p}^{(2)}}\cdots.

Moving away from the Bell numbers, there are still many fundamental properties of the generalized Stirling numbers that need to be explored. The Stirling numbers satisfy many classical recurrences and orthogonality relations, and it is an interesting question whether the generalized Stirling numbers satisfy similar identities. For instance, if 1∈S1𝑆1\in S then matrices related to the generalized Stirling numbers have well defined inverses with combinatorial interpretations [6]. In some cases, the answer is no, and it appears that refining the Stirling numbers to an arbitrary index set S𝑆S destroys some essential structural properties.

For instance, even in the special case S={1,2,…,m}𝑆12…𝑚S=\{1,2,\ldots,m\} the restricted Stirling numbers only satisfy the three term recurrences

{n+1k}S=k​{nk}S+{nk−1}S−(nm)​{n−mk−1}Ssubscriptmatrix𝑛1𝑘𝑆𝑘subscriptmatrix𝑛𝑘𝑆subscriptmatrix𝑛𝑘1𝑆binomial𝑛𝑚subscriptmatrix𝑛𝑚𝑘1𝑆\begin{Bmatrix}n+1\\ k\end{Bmatrix}_{S}=k\begin{Bmatrix}n\\ k\end{Bmatrix}_{S}+\begin{Bmatrix}n\\ k-1\end{Bmatrix}_{S}-\binom{n}{m}\begin{Bmatrix}n-m\\ k-1\end{Bmatrix}_{S}

and

[n+1k]S=n​[nk]S+[nk−1]S−n!(n−m)!​[n−mk−1]S.subscriptmatrix𝑛1𝑘𝑆𝑛subscriptmatrix𝑛𝑘𝑆subscriptmatrix𝑛𝑘1𝑆𝑛𝑛𝑚subscriptmatrix𝑛𝑚𝑘1𝑆\begin{bmatrix}n+1\\ k\end{bmatrix}_{S}=n\begin{bmatrix}n\\ k\end{bmatrix}_{S}+\begin{bmatrix}n\\ k-1\end{bmatrix}_{S}-\frac{n!}{(n-m)!}\begin{bmatrix}n-m\\ k-1\end{bmatrix}_{S}.

This appears to be the ‘best possible’ recurrence, in the sense that it involves a minimal number of terms. We conjecture that this implies that the generalized Stirling numbers cannot be represented as symmetric polynomials. Following [10, Chapter 1], when considering the polynomials ring ℤ​[x1,x2,…,xn]ℤsubscript𝑥1subscript𝑥2…subscript𝑥𝑛\mathbb{Z}[x_{1},x_{2},\ldots,x_{n}], the elementary symmetric function ek​(x1,…,xn)=∑i1<⋯<ikxi1​xi2​⋯​xiksubscript𝑒𝑘subscript𝑥1…subscript𝑥𝑛subscriptsubscript𝑖1⋯subscript𝑖𝑘subscript𝑥subscript𝑖1subscript𝑥subscript𝑖2⋯subscript𝑥subscript𝑖𝑘e_{k}(x_{1},\ldots,x_{n})=\sum_{i_{1}<\cdots<i_{k}}x_{i_{1}}x_{i_{2}}\cdots x_{i_{k}} is defined through the generating product ∏i=1n(1+t​xi)=∑k=0∞ek​tksuperscriptsubscriptproduct𝑖1𝑛1𝑡subscript𝑥𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑘0subscript𝑒𝑘superscript𝑡𝑘\prod_{i=1}^{n}(1+tx_{i})=\sum_{k=0}^{\infty}e_{k}t^{k} and the complete symmetric function hk​(x1,…,xn)=∑i1≤⋯≤ikxi1​xi2​⋯​xiksubscriptℎ𝑘subscript𝑥1…subscript𝑥𝑛subscriptsubscript𝑖1⋯subscript𝑖𝑘subscript𝑥subscript𝑖1subscript𝑥subscript𝑖2⋯subscript𝑥subscript𝑖𝑘h_{k}(x_{1},\ldots,x_{n})=\sum_{i_{1}\leq\cdots\leq i_{k}}x_{i_{1}}x_{i_{2}}\cdots x_{i_{k}} is defined through the generating product ∏i=1n(1−t​xi)−1=∑k=0∞hk​tksuperscriptsubscriptproduct𝑖1𝑛superscript1𝑡subscript𝑥𝑖1superscriptsubscript𝑘0subscriptℎ𝑘superscript𝑡𝑘\prod_{i=1}^{n}(1-tx_{i})^{-1}=\sum_{k=0}^{\infty}h_{k}t^{k}. Since the generalized Stirling numbers do not satisfy similar two term recurrences, they are not evaluations of elementary symmetric polynomials. Other generalizations of the Stirling number are, however, symmetric polynomial evaluations – [14] uses this technique of matching recurrence relations to establish that the Jacobi-Stirling numbers are in fact symmetric polynomial evaluations.

This is important because it means that there is no simple product factorization of the generating function for the Stirling numbers. More concretely, the classical formulae ∏i=0n−1(x+i)=∑k=0n[nk]​xksuperscriptsubscriptproduct𝑖0𝑛1𝑥𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑘0𝑛matrix𝑛𝑘superscript𝑥𝑘\prod_{i=0}^{n-1}(x+i)=\sum_{k=0}^{n}\begin{bmatrix}n\\ k\end{bmatrix}x^{k} and xn=∑k=0n{nk}​(x)​(x−1)​⋯​(x−k+1)superscript𝑥𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑘0𝑛matrix𝑛𝑘𝑥𝑥1⋯𝑥𝑘1x^{n}=\sum_{k=0}^{n}\begin{Bmatrix}n\\ k\end{Bmatrix}(x)(x-1)\cdots(x-k+1), expressing changes of bases of ℤ​[x]ℤdelimited-[]𝑥\mathbb{Z}[x], have no general analog.

Alternatively, Stirling numbers arise as coefficients of the normal form expansion of the differential operator x​dd​x𝑥𝑑𝑑𝑥x\frac{d}{dx}:

(x​dd​x)n=∑k=0n{nk}​xk​dkd​xk.superscript𝑥𝑑𝑑𝑥𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑘0𝑛matrix𝑛𝑘superscript𝑥𝑘superscript𝑑𝑘𝑑superscript𝑥𝑘\left(x\frac{d}{dx}\right)^{n}=\sum_{k=0}^{n}\begin{Bmatrix}n\\ k\end{Bmatrix}x^{k}\frac{d^{k}}{dx^{k}}.

The work [2] provides a comprehensive overview of work surrounding normal forms of differential operators. It remains to be seen whether there exists a modified differential operator which contains {nk}matrix𝑛𝑘\begin{Bmatrix}n\\ k\end{Bmatrix} in its normal form expansion.

Another interesting connection is to classical polynomial families. Applying Taylor’s formula (where Dn​f​(x):=dnd​xn​f​(x)|x=0assignsuperscript𝐷𝑛𝑓𝑥evaluated-atsuperscript𝑑𝑛𝑑superscript𝑥𝑛𝑓𝑥𝑥0D^{n}f(x):=\frac{d^{n}}{dx^{n}}f(x)|_{x=0}) to our generating function gives us

This yields a connection to the Hermite polynomials, which are defined as proportional to Dn​e−x2superscript𝐷𝑛superscript𝑒superscript𝑥2D^{n}e^{-x^{2}}. When S={1,2}𝑆12S=\{1,2\} (which classically yields the involution numbers), we can relate special values of An,S=Bn,Ssubscript𝐴𝑛𝑆subscript𝐵𝑛𝑆A_{n,S}=B_{n,S} and the Hermite polynomials. More generally, Gould-Hopper polynomials are defined in terms of nested derivatives of the exponentials of polynomials. Special values of those could probably be linked to Bn,Ssubscript𝐵𝑛𝑆B_{n,S} in the future.

In this paper, we have only established a few basic properties for the generalized Bell, Stirling, and factorial numbers. Their general definition allows us to unite the study of many previously studied combinatorial quantities, and will hopefully continue to yield new results about the classical Bell and Stirling numbers.

I’d like to thank Christophe Vignat for everything – I literally wouldn’t be a researcher without him. He also provided significant help with the probabilistic parts of this paper, and pointed out the connection to Gould-Hopper polynomials.
